title: Fossil Fuels Researcher  Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions:
Lack of consideration for candidates for a very time-consuming process.

First step, automated online video interview. They sent me a link to register my answers to 5/6 questions to talk about my motivations and past experiences. Exercise took 30min, you have 3 to 5 min to prepare and 3 to 5 min to answer (depending the questions). I had 2 weeks to complete this exercise which allows some flexibility. 
It may surprise in particular if this is the first time you are doing a video interview, because everything is timed and the software moves to the next question after the time allowed. But I found the questions easy and general, just need to be ready to build complete answers in a very short time period.

Second step, written assignment. 1 week later they asked to complete a very long written assignment with 3 parts: 
1)	A memo proposing one specific new research project (700 w)
2)	An internal memo proposing a three-year strategic plan for research and advocacy (1600 w)
3)	A dispatch (400 w)

I know researcher and manager in another department and they never had such difficult assignment. Although I had 1 week to complete it, this is huge! I spent a lot of hours (unpaid of course) to work and propose several research and advocacy projects and to think about a strategy for this new position.  I understood the division I applied for is recent and they are building their strategy and building a new team with creative ideas. However, as a researcher, I found the exercise motivating and inspiring as it gives a small idea of what you could do.

Third step, panel interview with 2 directors 2 seniors 1 associate. 1hour
First, I found the Hiring Manager (HM) and the panelists not engaging and not really curious: not interested in my previous research experiences or my field works or about myself. It was supposed to be a conversation but they distributed the questions among themselves. Very few follow-up questions and very few technical/specific questions. Most questions were the same as the video interview.  I quickly understood that I was not the profile they were looking for. 
Furthermore, we did not discuss the Written Assignment. I had no feedback for the hours of work I spent and the ideas I proposed. No follow-up questions about the strategy or the research projects I proposed. 

HUGE lack of communication from HR.
HR officer never answered my emails. There was a lack of communication since early in the process. First, when I noticed there was a typo on the due date for the video interview (I had to figure out by myself and contacted the video interview provider to get an answer). Then, I never had any update on my application, although during the panel the hiring manager mentioned that they usually get back to the candidate within 2 weeks and at this stage of the process - no matter the answer- they always provide an answer. 

I sent 4 emails (2 to HR/ 2 to hiring manager) not to mention that no one answered my thank you note after the panel...

After weeks of silence that followed the panel interview, I was confused when I find out HRW released a joint statement with other organizations on a topic related to the dispatch I proposed. It was even the same picture I used to illustrate my paper. Anyone might find this coincidence puzzling...

After my 4th email, the hiring manager told me that they were in the process of negotiations with another candidate, they were hopeful this would work but because of administrative constraints on their side they did not make a proper offer to this person but they were hopeful. In the meantime, they could not tell me officially that I was not the candidate they choose. He added that he gave me these answer because “I flagged” I have other opportunity. No kind word, not even sorry for the silence.
I really do not know how a manager could give such unprofessional answer to a candidate who spent so much time in a recruitment process (almost 3 months). HR could have just said that they are still reviewing the applications or simply that they chose someone else. 

Then, I received a month later a courtesy note saying they indeed decided to offer the role to another candidate and to thank me for my patience. They did not give a real reason except the common “a better fit for our needs at the moment”. 

I knew the process could take a lot of time but I feel it is unfair to push someone so far in the process and provide so little feedback, update, response and consideration. This absence of communication within the agreed time frame in spite of a very demanding/time consuming assessment process does not reflect well on this organization. Nothing could justify such lack of consideration and professionalism from Human Resources or Managers. 

I hope this review will help candidates to prepare and above all the HR and Management to rethink their processes.
Interview Questions:
What motivated you to apply for this position?
What do you consider the most significant human rights abuses related to the exploration, extraction, production, transportation, marketing and combustion of fossil fuels?
What experience do you have interviewing people affected by oil, gas and/or coal projects?
 What experience do you have working in difficult or challenging environments (such as insecure locations, hostility or remoteness)?
What experiences do you have conducting advocacy with governments or institutions?
What experience do you have interviewing people affected by oil, gas and/or coal projects?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions:
Overall: disappointing interaction with condescending HRW interviewer

First interview was with two people. It was very pleasant and I enjoyed our conversation. 

The next step was a skills test, which was around 2-3 hours. It wasn't difficult and just tested my ability to work under pressure.

I then moved onto a second round interview with a larger panel of people. My first impression was that it was very corporate-like, but it was almost expected given the size of the organization. It was going fine until the executive director of one of the teams gave me a scenario question, then kept giving me obstacles when I responded, and finally insulted my intelligence in a condescending tone. It had nothing to do with the original question or my ability to perform my duties in the scenario. Perhaps he felt threatened when I pointed out a gap in his scenario that would make it irrelevant? (This is me trying to justify his actions) Regardless, I was honestly taken aback by the level of disdain and disrespect, even as he tried to play it casually in a way that shot my confidence for the rest of the interview. The whole team then proceeded to say they have the nicest and friendliest team, as apparently not every department is great to work with (a red flag). Honestly, I never expected someone working for a human rights organization to be condescending in a situation where you're supposed to make your organization an attractive, not repelling, place. 

Prior to my interview, I had read "red flag" reviews about HRW under-appreciating Associates and treating them as lesser-than, but I gave them the benefit of the doubt. But ultimately, the interaction I had with the interviewers confirmed for me that I didn't want to work for HRW. If someone fighting for the human rights and dignity of all people treats a potential employee poorly during an interview, it can't get any better working under them full-time. At a human rights organization, it should be expected that staff uphold the basic tenets of human rights and respect others in the workplace. In these kinds of positions, it's necessary to practice what you preach. 

More importantly, though, I learned an important lesson (albeit at the expense of my mental health): do not compromise your values or self-respect over a job!
Interview Questions:
Why do are you a good fit for the job? 
What do you understand the position duties to be?
Was there a moment you received constructive criticism, and how did you handle that?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Johannesburg) in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions:
I applied on the Human Rights Watch online system. The process took about 3 months, with the hiring process lasting 8 weeks. I received an e-mail 6 weeks after the deadline for the position. The e-mail was an invitation to an automated interview. The automated interview was very easy and comfortable. It helped me calm my nerves because I had time to think about the questions before I answered. I answered 7 questions in total about my experiences, why I'm interested in the job and in the organisation. I received an e-mail two weeks later notifying me that I had moved on to the next stage. I had an online panel interview with 4 staff members from Human Rights Watch, although enjoyable it was hectic. I had a combination of scenario questions and general questions about my experiences, the job itself and the organisation. A few hours later I received an e-mail notifying me that I had a written assessment, the instructions of which I received the Monday following. 
They assessed my ability to draft professional documents, an e-mail, a short note as well as an invitation to a diplomat. I had 3 hours to complete the test. 
10 days later, I received a call from the Regional Director asking for confirmation as regards my references. They contacted my references and I received an offer a week later.
Interview Questions: Explain how your previous experiences will assist you in the position you're applying for?

The assessment included organizing an Excel spreadsheet, drafting tweets and Facebook posts, drafting emails, and doing research on various policies related to the office's work. I then had a panel interview with 3 people, including the person who would be my direct supervisor.

title: Senior Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (London, England) in May 2020
Interview Descriptions:
1. The  interview questions were pre-loaded in a platform, so you interact with a screen and you have about 1 or 2 minutes depending on the questions. The problem is that some questions are actually 3 questions in 1 and the time is just not enough. 
2. I knew in advance that the person who was leaving this position had some issues with her visa so she had to leave the post, not because she wanted to but because things got complicated or something. Therefore, I was baffled when one of the questions on the interview was about my immigration status. If having a work visa already was important for them, they should have screen that out in the application process, not wait until you shortlist candidates. It is a waste of everyone's' time. You are letting someone go because of her (American) visa but then you do not pay attention to that aspect  in the hiring process? My conclusion is that they don't ask in advance because is bad optics for them, which is BS. 
3. What is even worst is that I never heard from them again, I understand when they don't reply to all the applicants, but I was already shortlisted and I invested time preparing. A simple thank you for your time would have been nice.
Interview Questions:
1. Experience with social media platforms and broadcasts. 
2. Background with the main topics
3. Examples of conflict resolution 
4. Ways of improving/positioning HRW in mainstream media and socials
5. Immigration status
6. Anything I wanted to add

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: A few weeks after applying I was contacted to complete an online automated video interview. The questions themselves weren't difficult they were basic questions related to the position and my previous experience. However,  the automated interview wasn't ideal for me personally. Once you start the interview you can't pause or restart it and your answers are video recorded and timed. I felt panicked throughout and my answers came off as more robotic because I'm talking to a screen and a ticking clock instead of having a genuine interaction. I think a brief phone interview would have been a more effective way to screen candidates.

The next stage consisted of an hour long video conference interview and the final stage was an hour long in-person interview - they cover the expenses associated with getting to New York but have extra money to cover your meals, transport and visas and they will reimburse you afterwards.

Be very careful with these guys, they're likely stealing answers to implement themselves without paying you.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions: Friendly interview on general skills. There was a timed test at the end of the interview to note and summarise part of an HRC session. Did not receive a response after the interview but I did not follow up as I was offered a different opportunity elsewhere.
Interview Questions: How is HRW different from Amnesty International?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Berlin) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: In the final round there was a written part (1.5 hours, computer based) and a verbal interview with 6 interviewers. I had to work with texts and re-write them into various types of documents (for instance, create a memo out of an article).
Interview Questions: Motivation, background, self-assessment, expertise, salary expectations.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I had a straightforward 30-minute telephone interview with two interviewers. They were straight-to-the-point and it was hard to get any gauge on what they were thinking the whole time. The whole thing was a bit uncomfortable.
Interview Questions: If you were asked to research sexual assault on college campuses, where would you begin and how would you go about your research?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I sent in a cover letter and resume through the online system. They asked me to complete a 7 hour writing excercise, which I did, and I never heard back from the organization again. I understand that they cannot get back to all candidates that apply personally (as they mention on their website), but you would think that after I put in 7 hours of work, they would at least have informed me that I did not get the position.
Interview Questions: Provided with sample situations where the person had to write press releases, briefings, op-eds, etc.

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I had a 35min skype conversation with two staff members and then had to complete an assignment in 30 minutes. It was very fast-paced and I had to think on my toes. I recommend preparing a lot beforehand.
Interview Questions: What do you look forward to the most during your internship? What do you think will be the most challenging? Why HRW?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions:
Phone Interview after being recommended by another employee 
Somewhat long phone conversation, very polite and pleasant, expected questions based on my interest in the field and for the specific department
Received an email with an offer about two weeks after that
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Washington, DC) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: They first sent me an email to complete my application process on their website. Then, I was asked to do a video interview with the Associate. They told me they would get back to me in a week. However, they did not let me know until I sent them an email again after two weeks. They offered me the internship, but I did not take it because it was a remote supervision and I needed a direct supervision.
Interview Questions: What are your 3 strengths and 3 weaknesses

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: The process took about a month in total. I submitted my application online. I then had a phone interview, and then I moved on to the next round, with an assessment. Then I was called in for a face-to-face interview. They called my references and received an offer about a week later.
Interview Questions: How do you handle stress?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Aş Şayfī) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, got an email about an interview. Process was quite straightforward and transparent. I was told that my application was flagged, then was invited to interview. I was then notified when my references were being checked and when my application went through HR.
Interview Questions: Can you tell us a little bit about your background and how it makes you suitable for this position?

title: Program Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: Applied through friend, was contacted in a week. The woman interviewing me asked smart questions, wanted to know about my background knowledge and language skills. Nothing too crazy.  She seemed unsure of what she wanted.
Interview Questions: How different is this from your current job?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: They called for a phone interview. It was hasty and lacking real interest. They asked several questions about my personality but nothing about why I would make a great Associate or what experiences in my professional life would allow me to excel. I was cut off several times and it was somewhat rude.
Interview Questions: What kind of supervisor do you work well with?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: After submitting my application, I received an email a month later asking for an automated video interview which was 6 questions long.  About a week after submitting the video interview, I had a written "skill test".  I never heard from the organization after that and a month later saw via the portal that I had not received the job . This is one of my favorite organizations and have worked with them in the past, but the processed did leave me a little disenfranchised.
Interview Questions: Why HRW and why (specific division)

title: Europe and Central Asia Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I applied in early March and was contacted for an interview at the end of March. The interview process consisted of one phone interview with an employee within the department to which I applied, followed by a response within 3 weeks.
Interview Questions: What's a recent article put out by Human Rights Watch that you would like to discuss?

title: International Justice Program Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very easy and concise. I did a video interview as the first screening process and then I had an in-person interview in New York City.
Interview Questions: How has your experience prepared you for this job?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: Received an email prompt exactly 2 weeks later to complete an automated video interview. Once you opened the prompt, you made an account on a third party website to begin interview - questions were automated.  Asked 5 straightforward questions about my interest in the role and how they factored in to my career goals.
Interview Questions: Why HRW?

title: Development & Outreach Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: Video interview made up of only four questions. Fairly straightforward questions that asked why you wanted to work for Human Rights Watch in particular and when you're available start date was.
Interview Questions: What makes you uniquely qualified for this position?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Washington, DC) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: First, I had to submit a resume and cover letter. You were then emailed confirming an interview. You have the first interview, which is short and easy. Then, you have a skills test exam where you have to write a research report, and then a  second interview with senior researcher if you make it past the exam.
Interview Questions: The exam had you do a research report in 3 hours. Was difficult and time sensitive, but a little fun. Made it past, but got rejected after the final interview.

title: Advocacy Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: Brief, straight-forward and correct. I was emailed and offered a few options fort he timing of the interview. The interview was held in person with a panel of 5 people, working in a range of divisions across the organization. There was an initial conversation, presentation and questions, and finally a written exercise lasting around 30 minutes.
Interview Questions: What previous administrative experience did I have? What made me choose HRW as opposed to another NGO? Was I aware of the administrative nature of the position? What experience did I have with financial tracking and expenditure? What did I believe I could contribute to the position?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: I participated in an email exchange in order to assess if I met the basic requirements. This was followed by an in-person interview. I received a response about a week after my interview.
Interview Questions: What skills do you bring to this internship?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an application and was then contacted for a 20min video-call interview. 3 days later I was invited into the office for an in-person interview. It was a simple process.
Interview Questions: What skills do you bring to this internship?

title: Part-Time Associate Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed by two people simultaneously. They were very nice and asked me about my previous experience. They wanted to know in detail where I had gained the skills i mentioned on my resume. They asked me if I had supervised people before, trained them, which software was I familiar with. Another questions was " How would you old supervisor describe you?"
Interview Questions: Why do you wanna work for Human rights watch

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: I applied and went through a phone call interview. The interviewer wanted to know about my experience and goals. After the phone interview, the interviewer asked me for references and it took a couple of days but I got offered the position.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself

title: Multimedia Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: It was very straight forward. After applying through the online process I got contacted through email and then proceeded to do two phone interviews. They ask you the basic questions of why you'd be good for the position and why you want to work here. I was offered a position at the end of my second interview.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for HRW and specifically this department?

title: Development/Outreach Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: It took a little over a month for me to hired from applying to offer. The interview process occurred very quickly, I was called early in the week, then I interviewed a few days later, and then a week later I was given the offer. The Interview was standard, and very easy going.
Interview Questions: What interests you about this field and this position in particular?

title: Development Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Washington, DC) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied for the position, and a hiring manager asked me my salary requirement two weeks later since I submitted my application. Three weeks later, I received an email to record video interview with 10 questions, and I got an email to have a second interview three days later. The second interview was with two hiring manager through video conference. It was scheduled for 30 minutes, but we talked over an hour eventually. They asked a lot of questions about my qualifications, skills and experiences, related to the position. They did not get back to me for two weeks after the interview, and I sent them a follow-up email. The next day, one of hiring managers called me that I was not accepted because I do not have visa in the country where the job based. But, I was very glad she called me from UK, and explained why I was not moving forward.
Interview Questions: How you would work independently and report to two different supervisors?

title: Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Dec 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was straight forward with common interview questions asked. I applied online and then received an email a week later to come in for the interview. It was light-hearted and not difficult.
Interview Questions: What are your best and worst qualities? Why do you want to work here?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I submitted a resume and cover letter and then had a phone interview with an associate. A few weeks later, I received a call from the director of the division to let me know I had been offered the position.
Interview Questions: Mainly behavioral questions

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I saw the announcement for a Human Rights Watch internship online. It was a dual internship, assisting two departments at once. I sent my resume, references, and application materials by email. I then was contacted for a phone interview, an online skill test, and a video conference interview.
Interview Questions: What are skills you can bring to this internship?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: I had applied via the regular online application process and received an email about an interview. It was a relaxed conversation, but some challenging questions. The questions were mostly about my previous experience and academic research.
Interview Questions: My experience with doing field work and interviews

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very straightforward. Was about a 20 minute phone call. Interviewer was basically interested in why I applied for the position and how my previous experience related to the internship.
Interview Questions: Asked specific questions about previous experience listed on resume

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Brussels) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions:
Skype interview with a really nice woman who asked questions in a calm and precise manner. It was really laid back and informal, really great experience. I felt like I was really listened to and that she was interested in my experiences and sayings. 

In the end I couldn't accept the offer because of bad timing but if I had to do it again, it would be a great yes.
Interview Questions: Why do you think you'll be a good fit to the position?

title: Development and Outreach Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (San Francisco, CA) in May 2015

I had an interview at the office, and it was mostly a lot of behavioral questions: what I was expecting for the job, what I thought I could bring, any weaknesses I had, etc. At the end though, there was an on-site "test" of sorts where I had to draft an email and a mini bio on a possible donor. If anything, I wish that they'd give internships for undergrads to help with research rather than just host events.
Interview Questions: Can you run through your resume for me? What's your greatest weakness?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was easy. He asked me many questions like why I am interested in HRW and what countries I would prefer to work on. I got the offer
Interview Questions: Why did you choose HRW?

title: Africa Division Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Nairobi) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: it was quite smooth and informal. I was given an hour to work on translation on my own and I asked a couple of questions at the end on their expectations.
Interview Questions:
What skills I brought to the job?
Why HRW?
HR violations in E. Africa and how they were unfolding
Media platforms that I source info from

title: Senior Researcher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: Two days after sending resume and writing sample I was asked to do a written asignment which consisted in drafting talking points, a mission planning memo and an op-ed. After I sent that in I heard nothing for a month. Am now scheduled for a first phone interview.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: Took about two months after I initially applied (emailed my resume, cover letter, etc.) for them to contact me. Set up an online video interview with 6 questions (why I want to work with HRW, specific questions about the job). Got an email about 4 days later saying I passed the video interview and wanted to set up an hour and 15 minute written exam with me. I had to write a letter to a senior official, write an email in French, and proofread a HRW report and then format it. Never heard back after that, even after two follow up emails. Personally, I felt kind of weird about the organization as a whole after that experience. I understand that it's a big organization and everyone is probably really busy, but when someone takes the time to interview with you and go through an hour and 15 minute written test, I feel like the least you could do is respond back to their email and tell them they didn't get the job? Kind of turned me off to HRW to be honest.
Interview Questions: Wasn't expecting a French question during the video interview, so I kind of stumbled around with that one.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: Was asked for a phone interview, by came in for a in person interview, got the offer the same day. was explained the responsibilities and asked about my interests and knowledge of foreign languages. The interview was not stressful; I had a very pleasant interviewer
Interview Questions: why am i interested in HRW? explain my background

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions:
Applied to the job online with my resume, cover letter, writing sample and reference list. After a couple of weeks of waiting, I spoke to someone who works at the organization. Incidentally, that person connected me to the person who was leaving the job, who found my resume amidst a pile over 1,000 applications. 

I did not have to go through a formal phone interview. Instead, I was given a writing exam. The exam was one-hour and required email composition, document translation and writing a short report on your preferred language. 

After a couple of weeks waiting, I followed up and received a notice that I had to wait one more week. Then I was told I did not make it to the final round with the division's director. When I asked why I was not selected, they told me the other person just did a better job with her writing and translation.
Interview Questions: Provide Research and Analysis of the following issue.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: There were two rounds of interviews. It wasn't too difficult.The first interview was more general. During the second I got to delve into my interests a bit more and ask more in depth questions about HRW.
Interview Questions: This was such a long time ago. I suppose it is a bit difficult to come up with fresh questions during the second round. So one question I asked was for my interviewer to outline the differences between hrw and amnesty.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: Had a fairly short in-person interview after applying online. Mostly talked about my background and interests, as well as my knowledge as to how HRW operates. Make sure to do your homework and have some knowledge of the division you're applying to.
Interview Questions: What sorts of issues should Human Rights Watch look into? Do you think a human rights approach to public health is valuable?

title: MENA Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview which went over basic questions: my experience, why I wanted the internship, and my language skill set (Arabic language skills are a major plus). There was no language test but once I was on the job I read in Arabic daily.
Interview Questions: What was the last book you read

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Human Rights Watch
Interview Descriptions: I had one interview over the phone and a second interview in person. They contacted me by e-mail to set up both the interviews and the interviewer was great. It is a great place to intern.
Interview Questions: It was normal interview questions, nothing difficult or out of the ordinary.

title: Outreach and Development Intern Interview

Q: What do you expect from the internship?

title: Intern Interview

Interview Descriptions: Straight forward interview. Asked about qualifications, relevant experience, and why I wanted to work there. It was helpful that I had recently reviewed favorite Human Rights Watch reports to cite during the process. Straight forward interview. Asked about qualifications, relevant experience, and why I wanted to work there. It was helpful that I had recently reviewed favorite Human Rights Watch reports to cite during the process.

title: Development & Outreach Intern Interview

title: Intern Interview

Interview Descriptions: They were particularly interested in the 'why' - why Human Rights Watch, why human rights, etc. They were willing to find a role for me if they wanted me, they were not looking for a particular job description or anything. It was just a phone interview, not very challenging. I had my option of working in SF or NYC. Other interns in the office working for other departments had similar experiences I believe.
Interview Questions: Why Human Rights Watch?

title: Associate Interview

Interview Descriptions: There are 3 stages: phone interview with director that is about 20 minutes, then an in person interview with director for 30-45 minutes, and then you have an hour to do a writing assignment. The assignment varies by department
Interview Questions: Tell me something that you don't like about your current job.

title: Intern Interview

Interview Descriptions: Application through website posting followed by a short phone interview to cover basic questions. Then called in for an in person interview which lasted 30 minutes. Friendly and covered almost all 'top most common interview questions." Got a response almost immediately, very prompt with emails and phone calls. Friendly and approachable interviewer.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with stress? Name two strengths and one weakness.
